body_html:
Thank you, @rryan.

It's so fast on GPU that you can just compute them as part of your network and feed raw waveforms into your model. We compute all our features on the fly on my team at Google.

Does your terminal get flooded with the ffmpeg log whenever you decode audio on the fly ? Asked here as well. I could not find an easy way such as an environment variable for ffmpeg to turn off the output log, there's only a command-line argument loglevel but TF's decode_audio() does not support it. Do you have any suggestion ?
body_text:
Thank you, @rryan.

It's so fast on GPU that you can just compute them as part of your network and feed raw waveforms into your model. We compute all our features on the fly on my team at Google.

Does your terminal get flooded with the ffmpeg log whenever you decode audio on the fly ? Asked here as well. I could not find an easy way such as an environment variable for ffmpeg to turn off the output log, there's only a command-line argument loglevel but TF's decode_audio() does not support it. Do you have any suggestion ?
body:
Thank you, @rryan. 

> It's so fast on GPU that you can just compute them as part of your network and feed raw waveforms into your model. We compute all our features on the fly on my team at Google.

Does your terminal get flooded with the ffmpeg log whenever you decode audio on the fly ? Asked [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47361507/tf-contrib-ffmpeg-decode-audio-verbosity) as well. I could not find an easy way such as an environment variable for ffmpeg to turn off the output log, there's only a command-line argument `loglevel` but TF's `decode_audio()` does not support it. Do you have any suggestion ?
